synonym.title: Code embedding
synonym.code: # not supported in Python

synonym.title: Entry point
synonym.code:
# Python executes any top level code even if the file is imported. # If you want your code to only run from the command line, this is a common pattern:
if __name__ == '__main__': # This code is the entry point to the program

synonym.title: Detect language unavailability
synonym.code: # not supported in Python

synonym.title: Printing to the console
synonym.code:
# Python 2 >>> print 'Level completed.' Level completed.
# Python 2 and 3 >>> print('Level completed.') Level completed.

synonym.title: Modal alerts
synonym.code: # not supported in Python

synonym.title: Define a library
synonym.code: # Modules in python are single files # Packages are folders that contain other folders, # modules and a special module `__init__.py` # Libraries are collections of modules and packages, # eg. the Python Standard Library

synonym.title: Use a library
synonym.code:
# given a file `animals.py` with contents class Dog: pass
# import the library import animals fido = animals.Dog()
# import the class only from animals import Dog fido = Dog()
# import the library under a different name import animals as pets fido = pets.Dog()

synonym.title: Create + assign value
synonym.code: # Python variables are untyped... >>> myname = 'Aaron'

synonym.title: Default value
synonym.code: # no default values >>> myname Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> NameError: name 'myname' is not defined

synonym.title: Hoisting
synonym.code: # Python does not hoist variables. >>> def printname(): ... print('Hello, %s' % name) ... name = 'Bob' >>> printname() Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> File "<stdin>", line 2, in printname UnboundLocalError: local variable 'name' referenced before assignment

synonym.title: Final variables
synonym.code: # Python has no equivalent of "final"

synonym.title: Arrays / Lists
synonym.code:
>>> a = list() >>> a = [] >>> a = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
>>> a.append('orange')
>>> len(a) == 4 True # Generics are not supported in Python

synonym.title: Key-value pairs
Appropriate keys
synonym.code:
# A mapping object maps hashable values to arbitrary objects >>> periodic = { ... 'gold' : 'AU', ... 'silver': 'AG', ... }
# Map constructors can use keyword args, mappings or iterators >>> a = dict(one=1, two=2, three=3) >>> b = {'one': 1, 'two': 2, 'three': 3} >>> c = dict(zip(['one', 'two', 'three'], [1, 2, 3])) >>> d = dict([('two', 2), ('one', 1), ('three', 3)]) >>> e = dict({'three': 3, 'one': 1, 'two': 2}) >>> a == b == c == d == e True

synonym.title: Accessing values
synonym.code: >>> periodic['gold'] AU >>> periodic.get('gold') AU >>> periodic.get('XENON', 'XE') XE # You can assign to a key whether it exists or not >>> periodic['gold'] = 'Glitter' >>> periodic['Xenon'] = 'XE'

synonym.title: Sets (collections of unique items)
synonym.code: >>> fruits = set() >>> fruits.add('oranges') >>> fruits.add('apples') >>> len(fruits) 2 >>> fruits.add('oranges') # duplicates existing item >>> len(fruits) 2

synonym.title: Queues (FIFO)
synonym.code:
>>> from Queue import Queue >>> queue = Queue() >>> queue.put('event:32342') >>> queue.put('event:49309')
>>> print(queue.qsize()) 2 >>> eventid = queue.get()
>>> print(eventid == 'event:32342') True >>> print(queue.qsize()) 1

synonym.title: Raw strings
synonym.code:
>>> rawstring = r'The following is not expanded to a tab \t'
>>> escapedstring = 'The following is not expanded to a tab \\t'
>>> rawstring == escapedstring True

synonym.title: Interpolation
synonym.code:
>>> name = 'Aaron' >>> greeting = 'My name is %s.' % name
>>> greetingpolish = 'My Polish name would be %(name)sski.' % locals()
# calculations can be performed in string interpolation >>> element.style.top = '%spx' % (top + 20)
# Python 3 string formatting >>> element.style.top = '{newtop}px'.format(newtop=top + 20) >>> element.style.top = '{0}px'.format(top + 20)

synonym.title: Concatenation
synonym.code:
# Adjacent string literals concatenate. longmessage = 'This is a very long line. ' 'It is concatenated into one string.'
# Or use string concatenation. >>> name = 'Aaron' >>> greeting = 'My name is ' + name

synonym.title: Substring
synonym.code: >>> 'doghouses'[3:8] 'house'

synonym.title: Replace all occurences
synonym.code: >>> 'doghouses'.replace('s', 'z') 'doghouzez'

synonym.title: Replace one occurence
synonym.code: >>> 'racecar'.replace('r', 'sp', 1) 'spacecar'

synonym.title: Multi-line strings
synonym.code:
# Python preserves all linefeeds inside # tripple single or double quotes >>> string = ''' ... This is a string that spans ... many lines. ... ''' >>> string '
This is a string that spans
many lines.
'

synonym.title: Split into an array
synonym.code: >>> animals = 'dogs, cats, gophers, zebras' >>> animals.split(', ') ['dogs', 'cats', 'gophers', 'zebras']

synonym.title: Test whether a string starts with a substring
synonym.code: # Python string objects have a built-in startswith method >>> 'racecar'.startswith('race') True >>> 'racecar'.startswith('pace') False

synonym.title: If statements
synonym.code: >>> bugnumbers = [3234,4542,944,124] >>> if len(bugnumbers) > 0: ... print('Not ready for release') Not ready for release

synonym.title: Ternary statements
synonym.code: >>> bugnumbers = [3234,4542,944,124] # Python < 2.5 >>> status = len(bugnumbers) > 0 and 'RED' or 'GREEN' # Python >= 2.5 >>> status = 'RED' if len(bugnumbers) > 0 else 'GREEN' >>> print('The build is ' + status) The build is RED

synonym.title: Checking for empty string
synonym.code:
>>> emptystring = ''
>>> if not(emptystring): ... print('Empty strings are set to False')

synonym.title: Checking for zero
synonym.code:
>>> zero = 0
>>> if zero == 0: ... print('use == 0 to check zero')

synonym.title: Checking for null
synonym.code:
>>> mynull = None
# in Python 'is' is used for identity testing >>> if mynull is None: ... print('mynull is None')

synonym.title: Checking for NaN
synonym.code: # Python >= 2.6 >>> myNan = float('nan') >>> import math >>> if math.isnan(myNaN): ... print('use math.isnan to check if a float is NaN')

synonym.title: Checking for undefined
synonym.code: # Python does not have a concept of undefined

synonym.title: Value and identity equality
synonym.code:
>>> letterA = 'A' >>> charA = ''.join(map(unichr, [65])) >>> letterA == charA True
>>> number5 = 5 >>> char5 = '5' >>> number5 != char5 True
>>> class Person: ... def __init__(self, name, ssn): ... self.name = name ... self.ssn = ssn ... def __eq__(self, other): ... return self.ssn == other.ssn ... >>> Person('Bob', '111') == Person('Robert', '111') True

synonym.title: Function definition
synonym.code: # Python does not specify the return type of a function def fn(): ... return True

synonym.title: Return value
synonym.code:
# Use the 'return' keyword in a function # definition to return a value. def fn(): return 'Hello'
>>> fn() 'Hello'
# A function with no return value returns None. def doNothing(): pass
>>> x = doNothing() >>> type(x) <type 'NoneType'>
# Pythons lambda ;) >>> fn = lambda: True >>> fn() True

synonym.title: Assign a function to a variable
synonym.code:
>>> loudify = lambda msg: msg.upper()
>>> loudify('not gonna take it anymore') 'NOT GONNA TAKE IT ANYMORE'

synonym.title: Optional parameters
synonym.code:
>>> def fn(a, b, c): ... return c >>> fn(1) Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> TypeError: fn() takes exactly 3 arguments (1 given) >>> fn(1, 2, 3) 3
# Python functions accept optional and named parameters >>> def fn(a, *args, **kwargs): ... if len(args) > 1: ... return args[1] >>> print(fn('a')) None

synonym.title: Parameters with default values
synonym.code:
>>> def send(msg, rate='First Class'): ... return msg + ' was sent via ' + rate
>>> send('hello') 'hello was sent via First Class' >>> send("I'm cheap", '4th class') "I'm cheap was sent via 4th class"

synonym.title: Named parameters
synonym.code:
>>> def send(msg, rate='First Class'): ... return msg + ' was sent via ' + rate
# you can use named parameters if the argument is optional >>> send("I'm cheap", rate='4th class') "I'm cheap was sent via 4th class"

synonym.title: Variable number of arguments
For loops for lists
synonym.code:
>>> colors = ['red', 'orange', 'green']
>>> for i in range(len(colors)): ... print(colors[i]) red orange green

synonym.title: For-in loops
synonym.code:
>>> fruits = ['orange', 'apple', 'banana']
# 'in' notation in Python returns the element # of the list, not the index
>>> for fruit in fruits: ... print(fruit) orange apple banana

synonym.title: For loops for objects/maps
Closures and counters in loops
synonym.code: >>> callbacks = [] >>> for i in range(3): ... def fn(i=i): ... print i ... callbacks.append(fn) ... >>> callbacks[0]() 0

synonym.title: Define
Constructor with parameter
Instantiate
synonym.code: person = Person()

synonym.title: Reflection
synonym.code: >>> name = "Bob" >>> type(name) <type 'str'>

synonym.title: Check the type
synonym.code:
>>> name = 'Bob'
>>> isinstance(name, str) True
>>> not(isinstance(name, int)) True

synonym.title: Subclass
Operator "overloading"
Find one element by id
synonym.code:
HTML DOM manipulaton can be done in Python using different libraries and packages, to name the most widely used ...
- xml.dom.minidom - BeautifulSoup - lxml - html5lib
Which one to choose is dependent on the mindset and requirements of the Python programmer.

synonym.title: Find elements by combination of above
Iterate over a list of elements
Find out whether an element has children elements
Create an element and set its contents
Add an element to a parent
Remove an element from its parent

synonym.code: >>> import re >>> email = 'test@example.com' >>> p = re.compile('@') >>> p.search(email).group() '@'
>>> invalidEmail = 'f@ail@example.com' >>> [m.group() for m in p.finditer(invalidEmail)] ['@', '@']

synonym.title: Throw an exception
synonym.code: >>> raise Exception("Intruder Alert!!") Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> Exception: Intruder Alert!!

synonym.title: Catch an exception
synonym.code: >>> try: ... result = int('three') ... except ValueError as e: ... print('Outch! Detected: %s' % e) ... except: ... print('An error occured') ... else: ... print('result is', result) ... finally: ... print('This is run even if an exception is thrown.') ... Outch! Detected: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'three' This is run even if an exception is thrown.

synonym.title: Measure the execution time of a function
Request data via XMLHttpRequest
synonym.code: import urllib remote_url = 'http://example.com' data = urllib.urlopen(remote_url + "/data.json").read() print("The contents of your data: ', data)

synonym.title: Absolute value
synonym.code: # abs is a built-in method >>> abs(-4) 4

synonym.title: Ceiling
synonym.code: >>> import math >>> math.ceil(4.89) 5.0

synonym.title: Floor
synonym.code: >>> math.floor(4.89) 4.0

synonym.title: Random
synonym.code:
>>> import random
>>> rand = random.Random()
# Returns a random double greater than or equal to 0.0 # and less than 1.0 >>> rand.random() 0.55465114939258131 # Returns a random boolean value. >>> rand.choice([False, True]) True # Returns a positive random integer greater or equal # to 0 and less than 10 >>> rand.randint(0, 10) 1

synonym.title: Sine and Cosine
synonym.code: >>> math.sin(math.pi/2) 1.0 >>> math.cos(math.pi) -1.0

synonym.title: Convert a String to a number
synonym.code: >>> int('3') 3 >>> float('3.14') 3.1400000000000001 >>> int('three') Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'three'

synonym.title: Eval
synonym.code: # Python lets you eval() expressions >>> x = 0 >>> eval('x + 1') 1 >>> def fn(x): ... print x + x ... >>> eval('fn(2)') 4 >>> eval('fn("x")') xx

synonym.title: Adding a method to a class
synonym.code: # Python allows for dynamic manipulation of classes and instances >>> class Dog: ... pass >>> def talk(self): ... print 'bark!' >>> puppy = Dog() >>> Dog.talk = talk >>> puppy.talk() bark!
